HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 26, 1924
A WORLD'S CHAMPION FOR HOPKINS
Newspapers from coast to coast appeared last Sunday morning
with the announcement that Louis A. Clarke of Johns Hopkins University had lowered the world's record for the one hundred yard
dash indoors, by running that distance in nine and four-fifths seconds.
Johns Hopkins has had in its history teams to be proud of,
teams that have given the largest universities in the country a "run
for their money. To the best of our knowledge, however, this is the
first time that Hopkins has been able to claim a world's champion.
The remarkable race which Clarke ran on Saturday night not only
broadcasted the name of Hopkins far and wide but made the victor
a practical certainty for the Olympic games to be held next summer. It seems feasible to predict that a man who can run one hundred yards in nine and four-fifths seconds indoors will be able to
take something off of this mark on a fast cinder track. Clarke, in
all probability, will have a chance to advertise Hopkins' undergraduate activities on the Eastern Hemisphere.
Too much credit cannot be given to Verne Booth, the Black
and Blue captain, for the exhibition of stamina and grit which he
gay.e in capturing the gruelling five thousand metre run. Booth, who
was recovering from a recent illness, started from scratch, ran a
heady race, and did not stop until he had overtaken and passed some
of the best distance runners of the East. Booth did not break any
world's records but he delighted the spectators by his showing of
May we hope that Clarke's achievement will result in the elimination of a few more of the "oh, you're studying medicine" people.
THE FRESHMAN-SOPHOMORE RUSH
Colleges throughout the East are announcing the partial elimination or total abandonment of freshman regulations and lower
class "scraps." We have expressed our opinion on this subject too
often to repeat. Freshman regulations, such as are in effect at Hopkins, seem necessary to bring the first-year man down to earth,
to inform him of the fact the globe is populated by others besides himself, and to notify him that he is not really quite as good as he thinks
he is.
We would suggest, however, a modification of the annual lowerclass rush. Hopkins has been fortunate in the past in not having
had any serious injuries as the result of this classic. Medical men,
who viewed the tussle last December, however, expressed surprise
at the fact that no injuries of consequence had issued from this socalled organized assault. They emphasized the danger involved and
suggested that some other means be found to test the skill and
prowess of the rival classes.
It is an unfortunate feature of such affairs that it is not until
some serious accident has occurred that the danger and futility are
realized. Some December a freshman or sophomore will slip, a
mass of bodies will close over him, the student referees will not notice him or will find it impossible to remove the uppermost portions
of the pile and a tragedy will have resulted. And then a mighty cry
will arise to abolish inter-class struggles.
Such an occurrence, though it may seem only a vague possibility, would prove most unfortunate for the university as well as for
the victim. We would suggest that next year's Student Council
eliminate all chances for such a mishap by modifying the annual rush.

York in which the servants are
penniless but still distinguished
Russian aristocrats. Attired in
conventional but immaculate Tuxedos the jazz artists seemed to be
exiled nobles. The next link in
one's chain of impressions was the
decorative scheme. Luridly illustrated signs advised "No Kicking or Biting in the Clinches" or
"If the Baby Cries Take It Out."
The music was of the non-stop
variety and the dancers must have
discovered the secret of perpetual
in(,tion. Like slumming visitors
om another world appeared the
o-called chaperons.
The best "goil getup" was
voted to a ragged vendor of weekold newspapers. The most attractive male rig was left undecided.
Thus passed into history the
Bowery Ball which proved the
reverse of the old axiom that
clothes make the man: to-wit—
Fine feathers make fine birds; but
bedraggled plumes cause bedraggled birds.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 26, 1924
A WORLD'S CHAMPION FOR HOPKINS
Newspapers from coast to coast appeared last Sunday morning
with the announcement that Louis A. Clarke of Johns Hopkins University had lowered the world's record for the one hundred yard
dash indoors, by running that distance in nine and four-fifths seconds.
Johns Hopkins has had in its history teams to be proud of,
teams that have given the largest universities in the country a "run
for their money. To the best of our knowledge, however, this is the
first time that Hopkins has been able to claim a world's champion.
The remarkable race which Clarke ran on Saturday night not only
broadcasted the name of Hopkins far and wide but made the victor
a practical certainty for the Olympic games to be held next summer. It seems feasible to predict that a man who can run one hundred yards in nine and four-fifths seconds indoors will be able to
take something off of this mark on a fast cinder track. Clarke, in
all probability, will have a chance to advertise Hopkins' undergraduate activities on the Eastern Hemisphere.
Too much credit cannot be given to Verne Booth, the Black
and Blue captain, for the exhibition of stamina and grit which he
gay.e in capturing the gruelling five thousand metre run. Booth, who
was recovering from a recent illness, started from scratch, ran a
heady race, and did not stop until he had overtaken and passed some
of the best distance runners of the East. Booth did not break any
world's records but he delighted the spectators by his showing of
May we hope that Clarke's achievement will result in the elimination of a few more of the "oh, you're studying medicine" people.
THE FRESHMAN-SOPHOMORE RUSH
Colleges throughout the East are announcing the partial elimination or total abandonment of freshman regulations and lower
class "scraps." We have expressed our opinion on this subject too
often to repeat. Freshman regulations, such as are in effect at Hopkins, seem necessary to bring the first-year man down to earth,
to inform him of the fact the globe is populated by others besides himself, and to notify him that he is not really quite as good as he thinks
he is.
We would suggest, however, a modification of the annual lowerclass rush. Hopkins has been fortunate in the past in not having
had any serious injuries as the result of this classic. Medical men,
who viewed the tussle last December, however, expressed surprise
at the fact that no injuries of consequence had issued from this socalled organized assault. They emphasized the danger involved and
suggested that some other means be found to test the skill and
prowess of the rival classes.
It is an unfortunate feature of such affairs that it is not until
some serious accident has occurred that the danger and futility are
realized. Some December a freshman or sophomore will slip, a
mass of bodies will close over him, the student referees will not notice him or will find it impossible to remove the uppermost portions
of the pile and a tragedy will have resulted. And then a mighty cry
will arise to abolish inter-class struggles.
Such an occurrence, though it may seem only a vague possibility, would prove most unfortunate for the university as well as for
the victim. We would suggest that next year's Student Council
eliminate all chances for such a mishap by modifying the annual rush.
